Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 08:49PM mspradley wrote: Kelly, I am just over the state line and am also among those in your corner. Believe me, none of us have forgotten the freefall you are tumbling in, and we are here for you. All of my physicians and surgeons are in Charlotte and I was fortunate to have many friends helping me research the best fit for my diagnosis. I will be happy to share any information with you.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed... scared.... kjo bcisnofun

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2012 02:43PM mspradley wrote: I do not want to scare you, but please get a mammogram if you have not had one lately. I am sorry that I don't have time to read the thread all of the way through to see if this has been covered. My Paget's disease did not show up on the mammogram, it was found in the pathology following my initial mastectomy. However, my surgeon said that Paget's breasts almost always have either DCIS or IDC as well. Before you go nuts, remember that Paget's is extremely rare and for what it's worth, mine never itched at all. I would have your GYN check this.
Posts.Title: Itchy left nipple wilson33 Gingerbits

Posts.Content: mspradley wrote: I am 20 days post-op with bilateral DIEP flap and have had two post op appointments with my ps. I only have one drain left, in my hip that is still producing about 75-80cc of fluid daily, so it won't be coming out soon. All of my other drains, (3 others with DIEP, and two with prior mtx), would eventually produce the "straw colored" fluid with an occasional piece of stringy tissue included. I am alarmed because this remaining drain is producing a thicker yellowish, fibrous liquid, that builds up in the bulb what looks like Crisco/lard! My ps is not concerned, but I can't seem to find anything like this in my keyword searches. Any advice? Diagnosis: 11/23/2009, IDC + Pagets, 4.5cm, Stage III, Grade 3, 3/21 nodes, ER+/PR+/HER2+, BETH trial 1/2010-1/2011,6-TCH + Avastin 12-Herceptin + Avastin, 33 rounds of rads, 3/21/2011 DIEP flap bilateral reconstruction, 5 years tamoxifen Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Drain producing yellowish-fibrous lliquid mspradley mspradley

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2011 08:35PM mspradley wrote: I wantedvto follow up that I did see the nurse and she sail all was well with the drain. She said that the abdominal drains will have a different kind of drainage than the breast drains, and when you get a liitle dehydrated this yellowish (not straw colored) thick drainage can occur. I upped my water intake and my drain looks normal. I just wish it would subside so that it can be removed!
Posts.Title: Drain producing yellowish-fibrous lliquid mspradley mspradley

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 01:56PM mspradley wrote: When I was diagnosed and faced several months' leave from my face-to-face job in eduaction administration, I started teaching graduate classes online to stay focused. I am now going to retire from my day job to teach online full-time for two different universities. I have had several students who are in treatment and have found they really appreciate the flexibility of the online environment with the daily unknowns of their own situation.
